article.headline: Krauser seals win with free throws
article.story: PITTSBURGH -- Pittsburgh's tough game against Georgetown wasn't supposed to come until late February. Carl Krauser's two free throws with 12 seconds left allowed the Panthers (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) to fend off a determined upset bid and beat NAIA power Georgetown, Ky., 79-74 Monday night. Krauser scored 18 points and 6-foot-10 freshman Chris Taft had 16 points and eight rebounds as Pitt (8-0) led by as many as 14 points, then held on despite going without a field goal for the final six minutes. Marshall Williams scored 25 points for the Tigers (8-2), an NAIA semifinalist last season, and Brian Silverhorn scored nine of their final 11 points as the tiny Kentucky school nearly pulled off one of college basketball's biggest upsets this season. Until the last few seconds, the Tigers played Pittsburgh just as tough as Georgetown of the Big East usually does. "We were like a little kid who jumps into the deep end of the pool," Georgetown coach Happy Osborne said. "At first you say it's deep. But then you've just got to swim, just swim." Pitt led 71-60 after Krauser's 3-pointer but missed five foul shots down the stretch, allowing Georgetown to close to 76-74 on Silverhorn's 3-pointer with 18 seconds remaining. Silverhorn, who didn't start, finished with 15 points. Krauser, Pitt's leading scorer in all but two games so far, finally secured the victory with his free throws, and Jaron Brown added a free throw with 1.2 seconds to go. The victory was Pitt's school-record 28th in a row at home, and it didn't come nearly as easily as the Panthers expected, a fact they readily acknowledged. Pitt was forewarned by coach Jamie Dixon about the dangers of playing an NAIA school after Lubbock Christian upset Rhode Island and Bradley, and the Panthers appeared to listen as they opened a 40-26 lead early in the second half. "We didn't give them enough credit," Krauser said. "Coach said these guys were good and that Marshall Williams was a great player. We came out aggressive ... but I think we took them too lightly." The Tigers, often pushing the ball downcourt faster than Pitt could set up a defense that was allowing only 53 points per game, closed to 61-58 on Ryan Wilson's layup with just over nine minutes remaining. Pitt had held its previous three opponents to 45 points or fewer. Pittsburgh, yet to play a ranked opponent during what even its players say is a too-soft early season schedule, finally looked worried and immediately went on a 10-2 run finished off by Krauser's 3-pointer. But Silverhorn kept Georgetown in it, dunking off a putback, hitting a 15-foot baseline jumper, dunking again off a steal, then hitting the 3-pointer that proved to be the Tigers' final points. "We're not satisfied," said Williams, one of three Georgetown players who fouled out. "We came here to win." Taft proved especially tough for the Tigers to defend, scoring nine points in the second half despite missing six free throws. Julius Page added 17 points, Brown had 12 and Chevy Troutman scored 11. Brown played Williams and Georgetown's George Baker while in high school. "I never, at any time, doubted this team," Krauser said. "We aren't going to let anybody come in here and disturb that record and our winning streak." The game was the first played in Pittsburgh in a loosely configured exempt tournament called the Pittsburgh Holiday Hoops Classic but was, curiously, Georgetown's second game in the event. Georgetown's 81-67 loss at Florida State on Nov. 24 also was part of the tournament, though it was played in Tallahassee, Fla. Georgetown returns to Pittsburgh this weekend as the tournament winds up with tripleheaders Saturday and Monday. Pitt and Florida State already are set to play Monday in the final game. Georgetown was a last-minute tournament replacement for Eastern Michigan, giving the Tigers four games against Division I opponents, the most of any NAIA school. The Tigers have won 25 or more games in 16 of the last 17 seasons under Osborne. "We travel in vans, the roof in our gym leaks, but we have the best winning percentage in college basketball the last 10 years," Osborne said.
